对于暴雪的迷之定价以及背刺老玩家的行为深感愤怒！不推荐任何人购买此游戏！游戏是去年DLC1发布时购买的，当时购买的是豪华版，也算是暗黑破坏神的忠实老玩家了。就在今年12月份暴雪推出了DLC2，这本应让喜爱这款游戏的老玩家兴奋，但是游戏的定价却让玩家感到愤怒。购买DLC2捆绑DLC1，对于新人玩家来说这无疑是性价比极高的福利，但是对于早已购入DLC1的老玩家而言，这份“性价比”就是讽刺和嘲讽。想体验新内容？那必须以全价购买DLC2，没有任何针对老玩家的折扣补偿，相当于变相为已经拥有的内容再付一次钱。这种买新送旧的行为完全无视老玩家的权益，这完全就是在惩罚游戏的忠实用户。请记住就算现在是新玩家终于有一天也会成为老玩家。老玩家现在所受的待遇也会成为新玩家的榜样！一款不尊重忠实玩家的游戏不值得任何游戏玩家为之埋单！

Ich bezeichne mich selber als Fan. 1.) Fan von Blizzard ich besitze die Diablo-Reihe, die StarCraft-Reihe, die WarCraft-Reihe (RTS) und World-of-Warcarft 2.) Fan der Diablo-Reihe ich habe jeden Diablo-Teil durchgespielt. Von Teil 1 "The sancity of this place has been fouled", über "Beyond the hall of heroes lies the chamber of bones" bis hin zu "aaah fresh meat". Alles Momente an die ehe ehrwürdig zurückdenke. Ich habe Teil 2 gespielt - wie oft habe ich Rankanishu erschlagen, Wirts Bein gefunden, Deckard Cain gerettet... unendliche Stunden Spielspaß. Epische Zwischensequenzen. Meine Ernüchterung hat mit Teil 3 angefangen. Die Magie ging verloren, die beeindruckenden Momente fehlten, die Geschichte war mau.  Maßlos enttäuscht hat mich nun Teil 4. Ein Spiel, das an Beliebigkeit kaum zu überbieten war. Kein WOW, keine Emotionen, keine fesselnde Geschichte. Kein... DIABLO. Man musste mit Lilith und Mephisto vorlieb nehmen... man kann eben manchmal nicht alles haben.  Aber nachdem es kein Tristram mehr hat, nachdem es keinen Deckard Cain mehr gibt, die (ACHTUNG SPOILER) Horadrim ein lächerlicher Haufen ist, ist nur die logische Konsequenz dass es auch kein echtes Diablo mehr mehr gibt.  Kurz und knapp: ich kann Diablo 4 nicht empfehlen. Nicht einmal für massive Klick-Orgien. Einzig die herausragenden Zwischensequenzen sind - wie immer - bemerkenswert.

Blizzard превратила фанатов в банкоматы: сперва обобрала на Vessel of Hatred, а теперь гонит тот же контент по цене нового DLC в Lord of Hatred. Такой трюк — публичный хук тем, кто полюбил игру, и яркая демонстрация того, как алчность издателя затмевает ужасы самого Санктуария. Двойная касса за один продукт — удел тех, кто добровольно примеряет на себя роль дойной коровы с логотипом Diablo на боку.    Blizzard has turned its fans into ATMs: it first fleeced them with Vessel of Hatred and now sells the same content at full price in Lord of Hatred. This stunt is a public spit in the face of early believers and a vivid display of how a publisher’s greed can overshadow the horrors of Sanctuary itself. Paying twice for one product is the lot of those who willingly brand themselves as cash cows stamped with the Diablo logo.

I didn't want to like this game.  I'm a big fan of D1 and D2 and have over 1400 hrs on PoE.  That being said I got D4 and VoH expansion for $30 and am having a blast!  I'm a little confused on all the whiny reviews about microtransactions.  Its all cosmetic so just don't get the cool look for your little barbie dolls and get over it.  There's still lots of cool free cosmetics to play dress up with.  Also a  free pet and mount plus one of each with expansion so two to choose from for my $30.  Surprisingly the only down side is its easy so you really have to crank up the difficulty as you go which gives you tons of loot and exp, often 3-5 legendary drops at a time.  I discovered some decision paralysis as I built my character and found each 15 minutes of action could have me sorting through equipment upgrades for 20 minutes but I'm slow and methodical plus it will level out towards end game builds.  I started just putting loot in my stash and when it got hard I'd then go for the upgrade instead of automatically equipping better gear as it fell.  I found I might personalize it with custom enchantments then immediately find a better piece on the very next run.  So just wait till its needed or you'll spend too much time min/maxing than actually making runs.  Simply don't buy the cool cosmetics if you're poor and wait for sales if the expansion takes food off your table or idk, get a job.  Its really not even that expensive and definitely a fun hack and slash looter.

This game is okay. It's not awful, but it is overpriced to hell and back. The base game is $60, you get I think 5 classes with the base game. And the campaign is alright, not good, just alright. If you want a sixth class and an extra campaign story, $40 please. That is $100 for 6 classes and a campaign you can probably complete in 20-30 hours of playtime. This latest dlc which is basically the first one with 2 new classes instead of one is also $40.  Now contrast that with Path of Exile 2, which is in early access. The game itself is $40, no DLCs. It has (I think) 4 acts currently. I put 20 hours into one character and hadn't even started the third act. In addition, there are going to be 12 unique classes when the game fully releases. Though only 8 are playable right now. Do the math and decide which game is more worth your time and money.

As far as ARPGs go, it is one of the better ones I have played. People will say its designed to be a money trap and the microtransactions are out of control, which they are in the gaming industry as a whole, but if you're someone who can ignore the in-game store and all that jazz, then its a great game. Its not pay to win, but its pay to look awesome while slaying demons and stuff!  The skill system is a little lack luster compared to other ARPGs, but the gear system and crafting system can make up for those losses.  Overall, from what I gather from Diablo patterns and the community, is that D4 will be around for awhile, and its far from the best Diablo game, but it is a game that you can get plenty of hours out of, making the overall price tag more worth it in the long run.

I'm going to be honest, I feel pretty mixed about this game.  On the one hand, I would say this is the PERFECT game to play if you are a beginner to ARPGs. The controls are intuitive, the difficulty can be controlled, gear management is kinda fun, and it's very easy to get overpowered so you can focus on progressing through the game. I became a necromancer and it was great to just wander around with my skeleton army and shout "RATTLE 'EM, BOYS!" whenever I'd run into an enemy.  The main campaign is pretty fun, the side quests can be clever at times (There's a fun Hellraiser reference in there), and it's a game that's polished enough to be really enjoyable when you just want to wind down after a long day.   But.  The whole time playing, I just couldn't shake the feeling that I could get a very similar experience on a game that has 1/4 of the size. What's more there were more things that were wearing me down a bit. The 45-50GB updates, the always-online nature of it which can cause a lot of stutters, the ridiculous prices for cosmetics, and DLC expansions that just...don't seem worth the price for me, and just not a huge enough variation in fetch quests. Eventually it became so bloated in my Steam Deck I didn't think it was really worth it anymore and uninstalled it. As it's the Winter Steam Sale, I picked up 2016's Grim Dawn for a couple of bucks and, at something like 5GB, I feel like I'm getting a similar experience.  I wish there was a Mixed button for reviews here, because I WOULD recommend this game if you're new to ARPGs and it's on sale. But if you're more experienced and both disk space and getting a good bang for your buck is important to you, you'd do better just finding something else.

The graphics are good, the skill tree isn't bad and I didn't think the story was bad, but those are about all of the compliments I can think of. They turned Diablo into an MMO and essentially removed all of the roguelike elements from it. The world is the exact same every time you play, the only things with any randomization are the loot drops and some of the dungeons. The story is also focused around the player being the hero, but with it being an MMO now, the story feels disconnected from the world you experience it in. On top of that, it's a paid game that also has free-to-play monetization which feels like double-charging to me. Unless there's a return to the single-player focus and roguelike gameplay this will probably be the last Diablo game I play and I wouldn't recommend it for Diablo fans unless it's at a very deep discount.
Adding Paladin to the character selection was a great improvement to the game for me. I really enjoy the new class and am excited for the new expansion in April.

I have purchased D4 on release and since then have not played for three seasons. Here are the reasons:  Seasons 1 & 2, because the game on release was a horrible, unfinished, unpolished, unbalanced mess that was not fun to play. On release, there was only 1 necro build that actually did big damage, and they nerfed in the the first patch.  Since season 2, all the season mechanics were always about powers. It actually got pretty dull and boring around season 5. There has to be a way to make seasons unique without powers. Furthermore, the fact that powers to not transfet to eternal (unlike PoE, where some season meachanics become permament), this means that your season characters are effectively bricked forever once a season ends.  Now I have not played season 11 because I can't be bothered anymore.  This game has been out for more thatn 2 years now and all the devs are doing are fixing stuuf that is not working instead of addingg more content or any meaningfull endgame. They are literally reworking stuff for the 2nd or 3rd time in a row now. This game still has no interesting endggame. This game is still about faming the same bosses over and over and over again untill you happen to get the drop you were hoping for.  There is no crafting, the skill tree is a joke, there are almost no randomly generated maps, the game tries to force you into MMO shit like world bossess and raids.  Blizzard is not the company it was before and cares only about selling cosmetics, expansions, whatever for $50 wiithout imporving the game.

A ambientação está incrível, com aquele sentimento de nostalgia, para quem jogou Diablo 1 e 2. A narrativa também ficou excelente. A história te prende do início a fim. Ansioso para a continuação com a próxima expansão. O único ponto que me decepciona neste jogo é a progressão: os níveis iniciais parecem mais difíceis (embora tb sejam fáceis) do que os níveis finais. Chega num ponto que é um único golpe para matar 30 monstros na tela. O único desafio são pequenas mecânicas que te matam quase que instantaneamente. Esperava um desafio maior na progressão. Não vejo graça de apertar 1 botão e matar tudo na tela, com centenas de números saltando, sem vc entender absolutamente nada do que está acontecendo em termos de luta. Als jemand, der geschätzt 3–4 Tausend Stunden in Diablo III, noch einmal etwa doppelt so viel in Diablo II und unzählige Abende mit dem geliebten Diablo I verbracht hat, bin ich mit entsprechend hohen Erwartungen an Diablo IV herangegangen.  Atmosphärisch macht Diablo IV zunächst vieles richtig: Die düstere Welt, der erwachsenere Ton und das bodenständigere Art-Design erinnern wohltuend an Diablo II und teilweise sogar an den ersten Teil. Die Kampagne ist solide inszeniert, stellenweise spannend und erzählt ihre Geschichte deutlich ernster als der direkte Vorgänger.  Nach Abschluss der Kampagne verflog jedoch mein Interesse überraschend schnell. Das Endgame konnte mich nicht langfristig binden: Fortschritt fühlt sich zäh an, Loot selten wirklich aufregend und viele Aktivitäten wirken repetitiv, ohne den „Nur noch ein Run“-Sog früherer Teile zu erzeugen. Zum Vergleich: In derselben Zeit, in der ich Diablo IV gespielt habe, sind weitere rund 200 Stunden Spielzeit in Diablo III geflossen – ein deutlicher Hinweis darauf, wo mich das Gameplay langfristig mehr fesselt.  Unterm Strich ist Diablo IV ein atmosphärisch starkes, handwerklich sauberes Spiel mit einer guten Kampagne – aber für mich kein Diablo, in dem ich wieder tausende Stunden verlieren möchte.. Um nicht zu sagen, ich habe das Spiel nach Abschluss der Kampagne maximal 2 mal gestartet um andere Charaktere zu testen und habe dann noch im ersten Akt das Spiel wieder abgebrochen.  Wer will, holt es euch im Angebot, aber für mich ist das kein Spiel in das ich mehr als 30-40 Euro investieren würde.

[h1]Diablo IV[/h1]  spielt 50 Jahre nach dem Ende des dritten Teils. Mit den drei Vorgängern hatte ich vor vielen Jahren schon meinen Spaß gehabt und wurde vom vierten Teil auch nicht enttäuscht. Das Spiel ist jetzt nicht perfekt, aber gut genug für eine positive Bewertung.  [b]Was ich gut fand:[/b] -Story -Grafik / Cutscenes -Sound/track + deutsche Vertonung -Steuerung -Gameplay -Umfang  [b]Was ich neutral fand:[/b] Man braucht einen Battlenet Account und es gibt leider einen Onlinezwang. Wegen dem Onlinezwang hatte ich Anfangs starke Ruckler. Wie sich aber herausstellte, war das nur so, weil ich im Hintergrund Sachen runtergeladen habe. Ohne Hintergrundrunterladen, war das Rucklerproblem weg.  [b]Was ich nicht so gut fand:[/b] Hatte leider ein paar kleinere Bugs, die aber nicht so schlimm waren. Einmal ist mir das Spiel abgestürzt, was aber verkraftbar war, da das Game eine automatische Speicherung hat.  Ansonsten bietet das Game insgesamt 8 Schwierigkeitsgrade. Was eigentlich gut ist. Ich hab mit dem ersten Schwierigkeitsgrad angefangen. Immer wenn es für mich zu leicht wurde, habe ich den Schwierigkeitsgrad höher gestellt. Das ging aber leider nur bis zum dritten Schwierigkeitsgrad. Um die Schwierigkeit noch weiter zu erhöhen, muss man leider das Hauptspiel einmal durchzocken. Das hat zur Folge gehabt, dass ich das letzte Drittel des Spiels zu leicht empfand. Das war aber nur so, weil ich viele optionale Sachen gemacht habe und deshalb sehr gute Ausrüstung + Waffen hatte. Und weil ich eine hohe Paragonstufe hatte. Wer sich mehr auf die Hauptmissionen konzentriert und nicht so viel optionales Zeugs macht, hat dieses Problem nicht.  Wie gut das Endgame ist, kann ich leider nicht beurteilen, weil ich kein Interesse daran habe. Habe insgesamt ca. 90 Stunden für das Hauptspiel gebraucht und mache bald mit dem ersten Story DLC weiter.  [h3]Die Preis-Leistung finde ich ok. Wer mit den Vorgängern schon Spaß hatte, wird mit Diablo 4 auch gut bedient werden. Lohnt sich vor allem im Sale.[/h3]

На всём протяжении основной кампании не было ни одного момента, где было бы хоть как-то сложно пройти. Игра построена так, что ЛЮБУЮ возникающую ситуацию ты пройдёшь в ЛЮБОМ случае. Тебя убили? Возродишься рядом с местом твоего убийства, при этом ничего не потеряешь, кроме 10% от прочности армора, который можно восстановить у кузнеца — это ЕДИНСТВЕННАЯ причина, по которой ты можешь потерять свой армор, но только, если ты умудрился забыть починиться. Всё. Игра ориентирована на ленивого, это факт, за что получает твердейшую оценку 2.  Графика симпатичная, как и в Diablo 3, кстати, не скажу что сильно отличается. Но вот постеры в загрузках, особенно, после прохождения основной кампании, рисовались как будто лет 15-20 назад — неопрятно, непрофессионально, где-то даже как-то пиксельно. Видно что здесь разработчики на положили на это болт.  Diablo 4 разочаровала.

As a player who played at launch and snagged this again at the end of 2025 to play on my steam deck before the new expansion, I can say this game has come a long way and is in a decent place now as of this review. There is still room for improvement, but while not quite as good as previous iterations, it still manages to be a good time. I'd recommend during season play, or as a game on the steam deck while watching something else simultaneously. It's fun. Is it great? No. But it is good.  12-24-25 Edit: As someone who has played all of the Diablo games, I will admit the first expansion feels like it was written and designed (why on earth does Kurast look so different?) by a team who had never played Diablo 2 (at the least). Still having a decent time with this current season, but I can understand why the first expansion gets some hate.

[h1]The storepage is intentionally misleading[/h1] It does not tell you that this game has no single-player mode. It is MMO-like, set in a shared world (you will see and interact with other players) that is not procedurally generated. Not a single screenshot or paragraph in the game’s description tells you that.   Gameplay-wise that wouldn’t be a problem if the game weren’t called "Diablo". But for any player who has touched any of the previous three Diablo games, the name carries certain expectations, and the fact that the in-game store is full of fancy, overpriced cosmetics to show off tells me that this concealment is intentional.

시즌 1부터 현재까지 한 시즌도 쉬지 않고 함께 걸어왔습니다. 드디어 그에 따른 보상을 받는 것같은 기분이 아주 살짝 듭니다.  내 돈 주고 사서 플레이 하는 게임이라서,  보상을 받는다고 표현을 하는게,  올바르게 상황을 인지하는게 아니란거 잘 알지만.  음, 그냥 나는 똥을 좋아하는 모양이다.  그리고 이번 11시즌.  이제 슬슬 이 게임이 설사병이 나아가는걸까? 긴장을 풀 뻔 하긴 했습니다. 하지만 아직 긴장을 풀지 않겠다. 방구인줄 알았는데 앗찻차! 설사였구나! 하는 경험을 이 게임은 종종 시켜줬으니까.  이 게임이 앞으로 다시,  더 질펀한 똥이 되더라도 함께 지켜보며 걸어가보겠습니다. 그래도 고맙다 블리자드야.

DLC2 includes DLC1, but players who already own DLC1 get zero discount when buying DLC2—meaning old players end up paying twice for DLC1 for absolutely no reason. Meanwhile, new players can grab the base game plus both DLCs for just 488 bucks. Blizzard and NetEase are fucking insane just to hook new players.

Does Diablo IV have an well written story? No.   Does it have interesting and endearing characters? No not at all, no.   Does it have engaging dialogue that gets its hooks into you and bring gravitas to the situation? No it sure does not have that.   I was sent to find a character that went missing or something, idk, and i was like 'who could this asshole be?' Turns out it was one of the main characters that has been with me since the beginning and is a key character, i just forgot about him the same second he left the screen.   This game gets a lot of shit for its mtx. And i dont really understand why tho - because these are the ugliest skins i've ever seen in my life, they all make your character look like a sexually confused christmas tree. Its an excellent detterent to make you not buy the mtx so i am perfectly happy with that.   The gameplay is solid.

No es algo exclusivo de mi ordenador, si no de miles y miles de personas, da igual que tengas una rtx 2060 que la mejor gráfica del mercado, da igual 16 que 64gb de ram. Tirones, tirones y mas tirones, un problema de rendimiento que les da igual arreglarlo. Su competidor y mi juego favorito, path of exile , un juego gratis que le da 10000 vueltas en rendimiento. Llevaba sin jugar 1 año a este juego, he vuelto a jugarlo pero es imposible. Mi recomendación, infórmate antes de comprarlo si sigue habiendo estos problemas, y si los sigue habiendo, ni se te ocurra comprar un juego que no podrás jugar cómodamente, o tendrás que hacerlo en calidad baja, aunque juegues otros juegos en calidad ultra, como es mi caso.

[h1] Antes de tudo: estou NEGATIVANDO, mas sendo justo. [/h1]  Diablo IV desde o seu lançamento , é o jogo que mais joguei. Me divirto, continuo jogando e já passei das 500 horas somando PS5 e Blizzard (só no beta fechado foram cerca de 80h).  A franquia Diablo sempre foi muito especial pra mim, principalmente pela conexão emocional que tive com meu tio, que foi quem me puxou de vez pro mundo dos games. Por isso, essa crítica não vem de ódio, vem de frustração.  Comprei a Vessel of Hatred na pré-venda pra jogar de Natispírito. A gameplay é legal, funciona, mas a DLC como um todo foi MEIEIRA. Não é ruim, mas ficou um vazio claro — aquela sensação de que entregaram menos do que prometeram.  Não pretendo repetir o erro com Lord of the Hatred. Queria jogar de paladino, queria empolgar, mas a apresentação no TGA deixou claro: foi mais sobre vender a classe do que mostrar a DLC em si. Marketing acima de conteúdo.  Sabemos que empresa precisa de lucro, isso é normal. O problema é quando isso vem sem um ENDGAME de verdade. Aí o jogo vira um ciclo caro, bonito e raso.  Estou me divertindo com a Season 11, assim como me diverti com a Season 3. O gameplay base ainda é divertido. Mas a sensação permanece: muito dinheiro investido, pouca evolução real entregue.  Negativo não porque Diablo IV seja um jogo horrível, mas porque a franquia já foi muito maior — e ainda poderia ser.
É um jogaço, apela um pouco para a venda de cosméticos, mas ainda assim, entrega uma história fenomenal, jogabilidade e um endgame que tenho gostado horrores.

令人失望的贪婪之作——暴雪正在践踏玩家的信任  作为一名从《暗黑破坏神2》发售就一路支持到现在的老玩家，我对《暗黑破坏神4》“憎恨之王”DLC的操作感到震惊和愤怒。这已经不是简单的商业决策问题，而是对玩家群体的公然漠视。  一、赤裸裸的价格欺诈 国区售价从168元突然飙升至278元，涨幅超过65%！而所谓的“新内容”仅有一个圣教军职业，核心资料片内容竟要等到2026年4月29日才能体验。这意味着我们提前为不完整的产品支付溢价，这是对消费者的侮辱。  二、强制捆绑的恶意销售 最令人无法接受的是，新DLC强制捆绑已发售的“憎恨之躯”内容。对于早已购买前代DLC的玩家而言，这等同于强制重复消费。暴雪既未提供独立购买选项，也未对老玩家给出任何补偿方案——这种“付两次钱买同一份内容”的模式，已经触及商业道德的底线。  三、沉默比傲慢更可恨 截至目前，暴雪官方对涨价原因、捆绑销售逻辑、老玩家权益等问题保持绝对沉默。这种“掏钱时迫不及待，售后时装聋作哑”的态度，彻底撕下了暴雪最后的面具。  暴雪的“憎恨之王”真正憎恨的或许不是地狱恶魔，而是自己的玩家。
傲慢，无需多言！

I generally don't play these types of games much [i]deeper[/i] than the campaign + the DLC. So I have no comment on the endgame or meta stuff. From a gameplay perspective it's simple. It's fun to kill stuff in this. It's much more action focused, every class is able to dodge as an innate function. The ability progression is rather linear and quite shallow compared to something like Grim Dawn in my experience.  I don't really know how it's monetized and I don't care. I am enjoying playing the base game, that is all I have purchased at the time of writing. I have tried 4 of the classes. They seem to play relatively the same minus their theme and further progression. But again, it's lacking a lot of depth on that front.  I prefer Grim Dawn overall. I think Torchlight 2 is excellent. I miss the Monk from Diablo 3. Something weird is going on with The Last Epoch, and it seems to always have something weird going on. I get a lot of Book of Demons vibes from this as well. I just don't like Titan Quest because I don't like Greek or Roman stuff, whatever the difference is. And Path of Exile   I've just stayed away from.  My verdict: I'm enjoying this game. The combat feels good. It's fun to just kill stuff. It is, however, lacking a ton in character build depth, (from what I can tell) and it's monetized like many other games in current year. Horrendously. Hope that helps.

❌ 不推荐（来自一名 D2 D3 骨灰级玩家）  我在 暗黑破坏神3 里投入了上千小时，甚至可能上万小时。玩了多少年已经记不清了。 我一直认为自己是这个系列的核心受众：研究机制、深挖构建、长期养成一个角色。  正因为这样，我对《暗黑破坏神4》的失望，是结构性的，而不是情绪性的。  问题不在“削弱”，而在“抽走系统”  D4 的赛季机制并不是对角色的“调优”，而是对角色的“外挂式增强”。 当赛季结束，这些机制被整块移除，角色并不是回归平衡状态，而是直接失去其构建前提。  花大量时间研究和构建的角色，在赛季结束后：  强度下降不是 10% 或 20%  而是实际战力和玩法深度直接蒸发了三分之二  这不是平衡，这是角色身份被删除。  和 D3 的根本区别  在 D3 里：  赛季是变化与加速  系统是永久的  非赛季角色依然是完整角色  你研究过的构建会被调整，但不会被否定。  而在 D4 里：  赛季系统是临时的  强度依赖赛季外挂  非赛季角色像是被“阉割后的残影”  这对长期玩家、研究型玩家来说，是致命的。  最让人反感的，是设计动机  当角色在赛季结束后被大幅削弱、玩法崩塌的同时，又不断推出新赛季、新系统、甚至 DLC 来“重新提供乐趣”，这给人的感觉不是扩展内容，而是：  先掏空，再售卖填充物  我并不反对 DLC，也不反对赛季制， 但我无法接受 “通过否定我已投入时间的角色，来推动再次付费和重新开始” 这种设计。   如果你是：  喜欢长期培养一个角色  喜欢深入研究机制并希望成果能被保留  喜欢 D3 那种“系统可继承、角色有生命”的 ARPG  那么 D4 当前的赛季设计，很可能会让你感到被背叛，而不是被奖励。  我并不是没玩懂这款游戏。  恰恰相反 我正是因为玩懂了，才选择不推荐。

When Diablo IV launched, I honestly found it pretty mediocre. The gameplay felt repetitive rather quickly and I lost interest faster than I expected. Back then, it just didn’t fully click with me.  Fast forward to now, and the game feels significantly better. Blizzard has put in a lot of updates, improvements, and refinements, and I’m genuinely having a great time with it at the moment. The overall flow, pacing, and polish have improved a lot, making the experience far more enjoyable than it was at release.  While I still prefer Path of Exile 2 in certain aspects like gameplay depth and enemy variety, Diablo IV clearly shines when it comes to quality-of-life features. Inventory management, skill respecs, clarity of systems, and general accessibility are handled much better here—things I really miss when playing PoE2.  As a more casual player who isn’t heavily invested in deep endgame grinding, Diablo IV currently feels like the better fit for me. It respects my time, is easy to jump into, and simply feels fun to play again.

Diablo IV entrega uma experiência de combate refinada e divertida. O "loop" de jogabilidade é viciante: a vontade de farmar e lootear é impulsionada pela busca por itens poderosos e novos cosméticos que transformam nosso personagem. É recompensador ver o progresso após horas de dedicação nas masmorras.  Entretanto, as microtransações internas desanimam. Embora a Blizzard tenha acertado ao manter os gastos restritos à estética, sem impactar a gameplay ou o equilíbrio, o custo elevado de skins exclusivas em um jogo já pago gera frustração. É um título excelente para quem ama o gênero, mas que exige ignorar a loja para focar no que realmente importa: a matança desenfreada de demônios.

I played Diablo 3 quite extensively, but mostly focused on playing the campaign and leveling different classes. I was never very invested in the end-game and I approached Diablo 4 the same way. I really enjoyed my time with Diablo 4 and felt like it was a worthy successor to the previous game. That being said, I didn't invest much into the end-game, as I felt too much like a grindy MMO and I'm a busy family man. There's a lot of fun to be had here, but this game feels less accessible in the end-game for a more casual player, so keep that in mind if you're interested. As a casual gamer, who picked this game up on a steep sale, I can give this a positive review, but more hardcore fans might be disappointed by this one. There is also a huge focus on microtransactions that makes me concerned for this franchise and future games from Blizzard.  PROS: Even more build-crafting potential than the last game. A fairly engaging main campaign and I liked the DLC story as well. A great looking game that played very well on my system.  CONS: Locking the difficulty in the main campaign to 'hard' until you finish was a mistake. Things got way too easy towards the end, with no way of increasing the difficulty. The end-game is far too grindy if you care about obtaining the rarest equipment. Too many overpriced microtransactions.

It's a great game for a casual gamer. I return to it every 2-3 seasons or so and enjoy it immensely. For me it already has enough complexity and activities in endgame - Nightmare Dungeons, Pit, Helltides, Lair Bosses, World Bosses, Undercity, Hordes and some more minor stuff like the Whispers. Of course more activities in the future would be nice.  The one thing that's sorely lacking is their seasonal content - most of them were just more of the same. But this Season (11 for those reading later) is much better as we got a new class (although that's more of the coming expansion feature) and the lore part of it is cool as we are fighting against all 4 Lesser Evils for the first time in any Diablo game.  So I'm not really sure why many people say there is nothing to do - my understanding is that the content which is here is simply not similar enough to POE and other games that people love. So it's very subjective - for me POE was just too complex with their systems, so D4 is a really good fit for me.  EDIT: one thing however that is absolutely disgusting in the game is, of course, the whole Store thing. Having microtransactions is unfortunatelly the norm in online games now, BUT it can be done in at least a tolerable way. This is game is NOT it. The microtransaction model in this is probably the worst I have ever seen - the insane prices are targeted at whales only and you can only buy them using a special currency instead of clear real-world prices which is there just to confuse the buyer. It is mind-boggling that a full priced game with paid expansions has microtransaction that are much MUCH more expansive than the ones in free games. But it clearly works for Blizzard, because there probably are enough whales in the world to justify this.

[h1]Diablo IV – All Style, No Spice[/h1]  ★★★★★☆☆☆☆☆ (5/10)  I’ve played several hours outside of Steam on Battle.net too, so this pain comes with extra seasoning.  I should say this upfront. I am not a Diablo-for-the-grind person. I play Diablo for the story, and once that’s done, I’m usually done too. Same deal with Path of Exile. So yes, this review is from the perspective of someone who actually cares about the campaign.  And unfortunately… the story is weak. I expected something epic, dark, and memorable. What I got was bleak, empty, and oddly uninteresting. I just didn’t care about what was happening. [b]Lilith[/b], who should have been intimidating and complex, felt cheap and basic, like a villain checklist rather than a character.  What made things worse was the difficulty. I played on max difficulty as a Necromancer, didn’t follow any guides, didn’t min-max, didn’t do anything clever. I just picked whatever gear gave me the most [b]INT[/b]. And the game still played itself.  My summons deleted everything. Regular mobs, elites, bosses… even the final boss. Poor Lilith never stood a chance against my army of skeleton employees. I barely had to press buttons. Very engaging gameplay, truly.  The one thing Blizzard still absolutely nails is presentation. The [b]cutscenes and cinematics[/b] are fantastic. Visually impressive, well-directed, and clearly made by people who know what they’re doing. Unfortunately, once the cutscene ends, you’re back to the bland gameplay and forgettable story. Great visuals, no meat.  Would I recommend buying Diablo IV? [b]Not at full price.[/b] Wait for a sale and then decide. If you’re here for the endgame grind, you might love it. If you’re here for the story, don’t expect much, and definitely don’t expect it to carry the game.  Style over substance.

I'm a Path of Exile player but this is actually pretty good and it runs like a dream on Steam Deck which is a huge plus. The game looks good and isn't cartoony like Diablo 3 was, abilities are cool and fun to use. Campaign is solid and endgame seems to have a good variety of activities to do.  The only thing I wasn't so keen on so far is there are some MMO elements such as a large overworld you have to traverse with rotating timed events, waiting around for world bosses etc. These are public and my experience has mostly been having powerful players zooming around at 100mph one shotting everything while you don't really get to play. Luckily there are still instanced dungeons etc to do.  Despite that, my experience so far with the game has been positive and I'm looking forward to playing more of it.

Paladin is awesome, game has gotten a ton of positive features over the last couple of years. It's got enough build diversity to be enjoyable without it being an all-consuming experience, which IMO is a good thing in the ARPG market right now. There is room for more than one game to exist, this is the relaxing fun game for me, with POE/POE2 being the "I want to really think about this" game. That said, D4 has enough to think about that it doesn't feel boring at all, just a more relaxed take on things! The story is pretty good as well, and the art remains top-notch. Audio was a surprising aspect, I think it makes a large portion of combat much better because of the impact sounds. Overall, would recommend and I hope they continue to release more expansions/classes!

The game requires internet connection the whole time. I spend more time running around than killing monsters. Combats feeling junky and insignificant. And tons of microtransactions. The game was released after D3, and somehow feels worse than D3 in some important ways. The core issue I think is the developer simply does not have, or has no desire to have, a vision of D4. The current state of D4 gives me the impression that it has no idea what kind of a game it wants to be.

Diablo IV today feels far more complete than it did at launch. While vanilla Diablo IV impressed with atmosphere and combat, it sometimes struggled with pacing, endgame depth, and repetition. Over time—and especially leading into the Lord of Hatred expansion—the game has clearly grown into itself. Systems are smoother, loot is easier to understand and more satisfying to chase, builds come together faster, and the overall flow respects your time more than it did early on. It can still get repetitive, particularly during longer grind sessions, but that repetition now feels like a familiar ARPG rhythm rather than a constant friction point.  The story remains one of Diablo IV’s strongest pillars. From the very beginning, the narrative leans into grounded horror and moral ambiguity, with Lilith serving as a chilling, ever-present force rather than a cartoonish villain. Sanctuary feels broken, desperate, and believable, and later story content builds naturally on that foundation instead of trying to reinvent it. The tone stays consistent—grim, oppressive, and personal—which helps the world feel cohesive even as new regions and threats are introduced.  The release of the Paladin with the Lord of Hatred expansion preorder fits this darker vision of Sanctuary perfectly. Rather than feeling like a bright, out-of-place hero, the Paladin comes across as a hardened symbol of faith pushed to its limits. Sword-and-shield combat, holy magic, and oath-driven mechanics deliver the classic Diablo fantasy while still matching Diablo IV’s heavier, more brutal combat style. The class feels impactful without being flashy for the wrong reasons, and its arrival fills a long-felt gap in the roster, especially for players who missed that traditional holy warrior archetype.  Diablo IV isn’t perfect, and it doesn’t pretend to be. Some activities still blur together after long stretches, and not every season reinvents the experience. But taken as a whole—its improved systems, strong storytelling, atmospheric world, and the meaningful addition of the Paladin—it’s clear the game has evolved well beyond its launch state. Diablo IV now feels confident in what it wants to be: a dark, methodical, and continually improving ARPG that honors the series’ legacy while carving out its own identity.

Começando pelas partes que considera negativas: * Não ter banco entre jogadores; * No reino eterno é muito difícil conseguir itens míticos, forçando a jogar a temporada, o problema é que nem todo mundo tem todo tempo do mundo para rushar na temporada, isso limita muito, parece um jogo feito para desocupados; * Um endgame bastante repetitivo; * Storytelling preguiçoso. Tem uma lore boa, mas boa partes das interações com os NPCs são pobres, sem cutscenes básicas e linhas de diálogos mínimas do seu personagem.  De restante é um jogo muito bom, a progressão é satisfatória, tem uma itemização interessante, os gráficos são bons e as skills são bonitas.

Плюсы игры: -Очень крутой сюжет, мне очень понравился -Прародитель жанра "Диаблойд"(странно было б если бы было по другому) -Крутейшая графика, включая рэйтрейсинг Русская озвучка(для меня это очень важно), можно смотреть ролики, а не одним глазом пялить диалоги, другим-на происходящее на экране -Постоянные активности, вы не чувствуете себя одиноким и брошенным в мире Санктуария -Хорошая оптимизация, глюков/багов/статтеров мною замечено не было -Донат есть, но только косметика  И добавлю еще что игра стоит своих денег, очень дружелюбна к новичкам(привет ПОЕ), каждый день Вам есть чем заняться в ней! Не люблю близов, считаю что они контора п*дорасов, но игра 10/10! Если вы еще в раздумьях - брать или нет, ответ однозначный - берите! Тем более сейчас по скидке за +-2к рублей игра Вам подарит невероятные эмоции!  Все вышеописанное мое имхо, не нужно писать гневные комменты! Всем добра!<3

Diablo IV continues to be one of the most anti‑consumer experiences. The DLC model for Vessel of Hatred is deliberately confusing if you buy a bundle that claims to include the expansion, you still end up with half the items locked behind additional “Deluxe” and “Ultimate” DLC tiers. Blizzard didn’t just slice the game into pieces — they sliced the DLC into pieces too.  On top of that, the game still suffers from the same core issue players have been complaining about since launch: there is no meaningful endgame. This isn’t just my opinion — it’s a widely reported criticism. Players consistently describe Diablo IV’s endgame as “repetitive,” “shallow,” and “lacking long‑term progression systems”. Even after multiple seasons, the core loop hasn’t evolved into anything that feels rewarding or deep.

É o seguinte: detestava jogos isométricos e Diablo realmente me conquistou. Tem sistema de build legal, a skill tree você pode ficar a vontade pra montar do seu jeito, é divertido, e comunidade te ajuda a upar e tals. Considerando isso eu super recomendo ele pra todo mundo. Porém, nem tudo é um mar de rosas: a blizzard é mercenária nos valores dos jogos cosméticos, expansões e etc. O exemplo mais recente é a entrada do paladino (que resolveram cobrar um absurdo) e não levar em consideração para essa matemática os players que já tinham todas expansões (cobrando o valor full novamente).

I have fond memories of the Diablo games. I was 17 when the first one came out and it was a blast. I put a couple hundred hours into the second one. Even more into Diablo 3. I even played Diablo Immortal for a couple dozen hours. And I can honestly say, I really enjoyed the time I spent with those games.  There's something... off about Diablo 4. I hate to say it, but it's boring.   The cinematics are well produced, but the story is incredibly shallow. The Big Bad goes around corrupting everything and everyone. Townspeople? Corrupted. Graveyard? Corrupted. That church? Giga-corrupted. Your mom? Yep, corrupted.   I've played the main campaign for about a dozen hours and have gotten to level 40. Every quest is a variation of, "find my missing friend/relative/colleague; oops they're corrupted, go ahead and kill them, no hard feelings." They sprinkle in the occasional MacGuffin quest to liven things up a bit. "Find the Talisman of Lipschitz so we can cleanse the Temple of Shabbadoo of the foul corruption."  I just started skipping through all of the dialog because it's not worth reading and certainly not worth hearing. The voice acting is fine, but every... word... of dialog... is drawn out... so a single sentence.... takes a full 30 seconds to get through. You sit through a couple of minutes of dialog to get a quest that takes 5 minutes to complete and are rewarded with another couple of minutes of dialog and an item that improves some number by a fraction of a percent.  I love story driven games, but this ain't it. It has the trappings of a story driven game. Cut scenes. Lots and lots of dialog. But there's no story; the narrative is pure, hot steaming garbage.  So why am I harping on the story so much? It's a Diablo game after all. Action RPG, it's supposed to have a shallow story so you can get to the point of the game, which is killing monsters. Except there is strangely not enough of the killing monsters part, compared to other Diablo games. In the campaign, at least, there is so much travelling through empty space and listening to NPCs whine about corruption, that the 5-10 minute dungeon delves feel way too spaced out to keep my attention.  And the rewards for the monster killing feel too generic. You're constantly finding items that improve on the item you have by a fraction of a percentage point. So there is constant upgrading, but the gains are so incremental that it feels pointless. By comparison, in Diablo 2 you would constantly find loot your character couldn't use, lots of other garbage loot, and then occasionally find a sword or something that blasted your stats up considerably. Finding "good" loot was more infrequent, but when it happened it was significant and the difference was immediately felt. Similar story in Diablo 3, but to a lesser degree.  Now all the loot feels like it's following a predictable curve. Every 3rd piece of loot is an upgrade, but only by 0.3% of whatever stat. You're constantly swapping gear, but the fights all feel the same, even swapping skills around and trying different strategies.  I don't feel like I'll play this one much more at this point. I've already played for too long to refund it, or I would. I do not recommend this one, to Diablo fans or fans of other ARPGs. At least I got it on sale for half price, I guess.

I waited a few years after this game released to try it because of life circumstance and situation. I waited for a 40% off sale Christmas of 2025. I played for nearly 7 hours, then I stopped. At this point, I wish I could refund the game.   Diablo 4 has no soul or identity. The core gameplay no longer feels like the Diablo franchise. I played a Rogue to lvl 25 and it never once felt good. It feels clunky, overwrought, and incomplete. Using a skill did not feel good. I cannot quite place my finger on it, but the magic of the Diablo series dies with this game.   I am now considering going back to play Diablo 2. I played that game for hundreds upon hundreds of hours as a kid. Am I simply wearing rose-tinted glasses? Have I become a bitter middle-aged guy? Do I simply long for a simpler time? I am not sure.   What I do know for sure is that I would encourage you, dear review reader, to not purchase this game.

Diablo IV - это не игра, это финансовая стратегия Blizzard по доению всего, что дышит и имеет карту с деньгами. Когда-то Diablo был про ад, демонов и лут. Теперь главный босс - ваша кредитная карточка [list] [*]Полноценная игра за фуллпрайс? Купил. [*]Боевой пропуск? Купил. [*]Косметика по цене инди-игры? Купил. [/list]  А теперь держи DLC, где класс персонажа продаётся отдельно, потому что почему бы и нет  Blizzard, видимо, решили: [i]«А давайте базовую игру продавать как демо, а остальное - по кусочкам, как колбасу в 90-х»[/i]  [b]Ты платишь как за AAA, а получаешь ощущение, что тебя аккуратно, без резких движений, разводят как гоя. Причём с улыбкой и словами «мы прислушиваемся к сообществу». Да-да, прислушиваетесь - к звуку списания средств с карты[/b]  Особенно умиляет логика: Новый класс? -💸 Новый контент? -💸  Фикс старых проблем? Ну… может быть потом, но вот тебе новый скин за 25 баксов  Diablo IV - это когда ты заходишь в игру убивать демонов, а в итоге понимаешь, что демон тут ты, потому что добровольно участвуешь в этом цирке. И каждый сезон Blizzard проверяет: а насколько ещё глубоко можно залезть игроку в жопу, чтобы он сказал «спасибо»?

Хорошая игра, но…  Игра действительно хорошая, однако после того как я понял, что в ней буквально нет никакой глобальной цели, а всё, что ты делаешь, нормально сохранить невозможно без доната, я сильно разочаровался.  Возможно, я чего-то не понял, но по факту выходит так: как только заканчивается сезон (а он длится около полугода), тебе сбрасывают почти весь прогресс, который ты прокачивал. Да, в игре есть режим для героя, где сезоны не влияют на твой мир, но он ужасно скучный и полностью убивает ощущение развития.  Цены на DLC постоянно растут, а без них тебе просто отрезают половину карты. В итоге выбор простой: донать или терпи.  При этом, если полностью исключить донат - игра шикарная для своего жанра, и видно, что многие механики сделаны с расчётом на игроков. Но вся эта система сезонов и DLC перечёркивает большую часть удовольствия.

Si vous aimez les jeux où vous pouvez massacrer des hordes de démons sans culpabilité, Diablo IV est fait pour vous ! C’est un peu comme une thérapie, mais avec plus de monstres et moins de divan. Entre les graphismes qui déchirent et les combats qui vous donnent l’impression d’être un super-héros badass, vous ne verrez pas le temps passer. En plus, c’est l’excuse parfaite pour éviter les corvées : « Désolé, je suis en pleine mission pour sauver le monde… encore une fois. » Bref, Diablo IV, c’est le cocktail parfait entre action, fun et un bon gros shoot d’adrénaline. À vos manettes, prêts, démons !

“Money, honey, give us all your money.”  I honestly don’t understand what exactly I’m paying for. I can’t say the game has any truly outstanding or unique content. I can’t say that the expansions are worth the price of a full game. I can’t play with my friends, because they believe (and I agree with them) that the expansions are not worth that kind of money. (The same criticism applies to WoW, by the way.)  You have a lot of cosmetic sets that cost a significant amount of money. You sell an expensive base edition. You also have a battle pass in the game.  So I really don’t understand: are you trying to make a game that everyone wants to play, or a game designed to squeeze as much money as possible out of the few remaining fans of the franchise?

It's a fun game overall. My only previous history with the series was the original Diablo on PC.   With Diablo 4, I enjoy the gameplay and controls. The story is decent and enjoyable enough to follow with. A small handful of the dungeons felt cookie-cutter but for the most part I was impressed with some of the variety from dungeon-to-dungeon.   I did not get too much into the weapon/armor gem customization but I found the RPG aspect overall fun and not too overwhelming. There are enough opportunities to put emphasis on melee vs range vs magic as the RPG system progresses.   Worth the initial $40 I paid.

So fa dessa empresa mercenaria a muitos anos. So de wow devo ter mais de 15. Comecei nos ARPGS no Grim dawn, e depois peguei o Diablo 4. O jogo é bom sim, o que me deixa pistola e que paguei por uma expansao e jogo base, e uma SEMANA DEPOIS ANUNCIARAM OUTRA EXPANSAO E O PACOTE COMPLETO FOI O MESMO QUE PAGUEI EM APENAS UMA. Fiquei extremamente PUTO, tentei reembolso mas ja tinha passado o tempo. Jogo ainda pq realmente achei o jogo bom, gosto de POE mas Diablo tem o que eu amo em rpgs que e respeito a fantasia de classe. Alem de tudo a loja com passe de batalha e extremamente limitada em relacao principalmente a montarias e cosmeticos legais. Alem de pagar o jogo voce tem que pagar pra ter um passe de batalha decente. E nao e nada barato. "Ah mas tem como farmar a moeda no jogo", Tem sim, o pacote custa 2800 e voce consegue farmar 400 a cada 80 dias. Se tiver outra forma me avisem por favor. Montarias que voce consegue com o passe padrao e basicamente cavalos, cavalo roxo, azul, preto, manco, etc....   O jogo é bom sim, to jogando e vou jogar ate enjoar, mas nao recomendo entrar nessa descabelacao de palhaco se ainda tem seu dinheiro. Peguem um POE 2 que serao mais felizes. Infelizmente a blizzard faz jogos que me atraem demais, eu sei que estou errado: Um pobre nao pode gostar de jogos da blizzard.   TLDR: Se tiver dinheiro sobrando compra ao inves de jogar no tigrinho, mas aconselho  mais a comprar outro ARPG menos mercenario um fazer uma despesa de mercado pra alguem que precise.
Um Diablo OK. Acho que gostei mais do III do que desse.

I'm done with Blizzard..... The company has gone from a Genre setting example to an example of corporate greed.   I was one of the foolish to have purchased the VoH expansion thinking that it I would be able to enjoy it and get future DLC as they come out only to be stabbed in the back when they delist it and include it as part of LoH without any discout or consideration for those that have already purchased VoH.  The real kicker?  I've owned Diablo 4 for over a year and have only been able to get 2 hours of game time in..... From the constant crashes, disconnects (Yeah, need to be online for a single player session) and game locking bugs that Blizzard never seems to care about fixing instead focusing on pumping out more DLC and microtransactions to rake in cash rather then fixing the bugs.  And when they do release a patch?  Good luck installing it...... Game is over 100GB installed, then you need 16GB for downloading the patch... OK that's reasonable.... But add another 100GB to patch the files since it will make a copy of the file while patching..... and need another 100GB on my OS drive since I didn't install it to my OS drive but steam needs to download the patch, patch the files on the OS drive and then copy it over to the game drive (While leaving the existing copy there).   So over 300GB needed for this game....   Again absolutely insane in this day and age when you can patch in-situ.    After all if a file gets corrupted during the patch steam can do an integrity check and redownload it.    In fact it's easier to uninstall the game and re-install it everytime there is a patch rather then attempting to patch it.

Дорого и наплевательски. Кусок вылетающего говна с платными DLC по цене базовой игры. С выходом 11-ого сезона ошибка "Diablo IV detected corrupted data and was unable to automatically repair damage" стала посещать мой взор в 3 раза чаще. И ладно, если бы после вылета игру можно было сразу запустить. Нет. Ждите проверку файлов 25 минут.  Для справки: первое упоминание об этой ошибке было еще в 3-ем сезоне. На все просьбы и мольбы от фанатов, "Уважаемые" близзарды не удосужились ее исправить по сей день. Та же ситуация с донатом через стим. Если бабки не дошли - это исключительно ваши проблемы. В общем и целом, разрабы срать хотели на ваше мнение, как игрока. Жрите, что дают.

Played it on the Blizz client on launch. Had a ton of fun leveling through the base game and had fun with the hadnful; of classes, but as a live service game I've never really understood the idea of just playing a new expendable character every season. It feels like you just level up and grind up a useless character only to complete a meaningless checklist of activities to earn cosmetics that you can use the next season. Only for the cycle to continue next season. I know it will never happen but I wish it was more like an MMO and I could just have 1 character that I do everything on... Overall it's a good time if you're looking for a mindless hack and slash grindy game to play while watching videos.

This game is alright but not worth the cost. In this genre of games it's like "you're paying for the brand" vs a high quality competitor in the genre. I've owned this game on battle net and didn't play after the first dlc dropped. I saw the new dlc offering paladin so that peaked my interest as I mained crusader in Diablo 3. I picked it up on steam so I had another game to play on my steam deck but honestly I wish I hadn't.   The content is generally dry and  repetitive which if this were an indie company I'd be okay with but with a multi billion dollar company it's about as much as you expect, they charge you full price for a game that just makes you do the same stuff over and over for better gear that you can use to do the same stuff over and over. It's really just an empty gameplay loop. If you're a satisfied goldfish that likes to spend $70+ and $20 on each cosmetic to run the same dungeons and repeat the same helltide event for hours on end then more power to you, I wish I too could be easily entertained.

While the game is extremely overpriced, this review is for POE players and players that have day job don't mind indulging themselves fun with their hard earned money in very little time they got.   Short version: If you like diablo lore, cutscenes and coherent story telling. Some class like paladin and you got a few hundred buck spared. Diablo is worth a campaign. If you're looking for gameplay and endgame gameplay content. Save yourself some money and stick with POE/POE2.  Diablo 4 does a good job putting coherent story line and story telling better than POE. I've actually like the lore and cutscene. I find myself looking up lore and previous diablo game's trailer to get immersive in that. Where in POE story is really only used as a an excuse to get you to fight the bosses.  Gameplay is where this diablo weaker. In POE games the skills and ability are bind to gems and technically can be equipped by almost all the class, such that abilities are much more generic which allows for much more interesting combination and build. Class in POE are really more of a template. But in reality people tends to build what's stronger and they tends to feel and play more or less the same even between different classes.  Diablo 4 in this regard do a bit better in which making class more distinct. All the class in the diablo feel really different due to the ability are bind to each class. But where diablo suck is the ability slot is much fewer. You only have 6 slot at any given time where in POE you can have 9 active slot. That allow for fun element where maybe only 5-6 of these skills is what carry the game but you have additional 4 slot for extra junk but fun ability just for the pure spectacle of it.   Visual, for the most part, both games feels suspiciously similar in their world and level design. But the diablo's world design particularly during campaign is really good and immersive in the story they're trying to portray. Diablo 4's character model is actually more pleasing too. There are a few times with real time cutscenes where you can see your character close up and it's always exciting.  Item mechanics also better in diablo4 than POE2, at least currently. Overall diablo4 isn't as bad as people making out to be. Overpriced and money trap? sure, especially for people like me who enjoy cosmetics. Practically though the amount of money I've spent in both POE/POE2 is actually more than what I spent in diablo4 base game + DLCs + some cosmetic.  But this is not to overlook the fact that blizzard greedy tactics especially how they handle vassal of hatred DLC owner in next expansion pack lord of hatred.

it's not that bad of a game .. but technical issues (stuttering, memory leaks etc.) and corporate greed (riddled with expensive dlc and microtransactions) really sour the experience for what's supposed to be a "premium" game.

对于暗黑4的评价 这款游戏总体就是一坨狗屎， 这是一款让你看着还行，但购买后包你恶心加后悔的游戏， 暴雪对自己的狗屎过于自信，不是3A卖的比3A还贵， 任务非常枯燥，玩两任务就枯燥的打瞌睡。 建模奇丑，过于政治正确，在你建角色时请赶紧退款，不然接下来就会后悔退款退的晚了， 这是一款B站视频，steam社区在任何steam打折期间做的推荐视频里都不会提起的游戏，（这款游戏推给大家买了之后包大家骂声一片取关拉黑） 暴雪还存在背刺玩家，当你枯燥的想雇个佣兵时会发现还的再花二百买它的DLC憎恨之刺。 游戏内装备系统做的让玩家毫无参与感，装备系统做的像国内廉价挂机页游，一刀999那种。 还有全程联网，延迟高，垮平台登陆等烦人的骚操作。 我家臭宝玩暗黑4玩了十分钟头晕想吐，强迫玩了半小时实在玩不下去了，打开手机看国产短剧去了， 我坚持玩了几个小时，枯燥乏味瞌睡加极度恶心想吐，我的评价是还不如来把斗地主或者昆特牌有意思。

Although incredibly repetitive the team play on this game is excellent and killing demons just feels good. The graphics are excellent and the new ways to enhance equipment and upgrades allows for a more personalized play experience.

The game is fun, i wish you could play the different seasons on a single character and not make a new one each season. However this is how most games like this work so i wont be too harsh on that aspect.   Overall the game is pretty fun to kill some time, there is a ton of different things to keep you busy. A lot of people complain about the microtransactions but its cosmetics only and you don't ever even need to visit the shop if you don't want to buy any cosmetic skins.   People are also upset about the latest expansion being bundled together with the old one but blizzard does this with WoW too so I'm not sure why people are shocked that they use the same type of bundled system here. (When a new expansion for WoW is released all of the old content becomes bundled together when you subscribe and you need to purchase each new one at full price).  While i do recommend the game wait for a sale and pickup the base game plus dlc together. Game is also a lot more fun playing with other people- if you have some friends with the game i'd suggest grouping up or there is a chat in game/recruitment board/clans that you can find groups of people to play with.

D'après ce que je peux entrevoir, Diablo 4 devient un MMORPG après avoir fini la campagne en solo ... A voir. Si vous voulez aller loin, ne jeter rien! Même (et surtout) les caches (boites cadeaux) car elles sortent toujours des items en fonction de votre niveau et vous n'en avez vraiment pas besoin en campagne. Bref, pour l'instant j'adhère ;)

Before you buy, know this:  It requires a third party program/ account (like Steam) Battle Net. The program sucks. Extremely long load times. Doesnt always read that youre online. Lots of error messages. Then once you down load it, you have to link or connect the accounts. Once its linked, you open the game on Steam, and it sends you to an Online server. You will be taken to the start menu IF Battle net has connected and logged you in. Log in is supposed to be automatic once you open the app, like steam. If youre not logged in, it will send you an error message and closes the game. (you have no control of this). Sometime it takes several attempts to start the game. Now once you get into the game, because its an Online sever, there are no options to save the game, and sometimes you have to go back and redo certain areas to get back what you lost. Just be aware of that. I say this because there are times where I get kicked off the server (for reasons unknown to me). A server crash? Over heating cpu/gpu? Not Sure.  If you can get past all that jazz, its a beautiful game. Large HD monitor recommended.   PS if you know a way to help make my battlenet run smoother im all ears.

Eu jogo Diablo desde o 1 e joguei TODOS, ok? Todos. E essa é a diferença de um fã para um fanboy, certo? Vou deixar aqui a diferença de um fã para um fanboy. Eu sou fã de Diablo: joguei todos e zerei todos, certo? Tanto os principais quanto os spin-offs. Ééé… eu gostei demais do Diablo I, II e III.  Dito isso, a Blizzard faz jus aos acontecimentos envolvendo seus funcionários e nos assedia com esse jogo extremamente patético e cheio de microtransações que é o Diablo IV. História bem mediana, com um fechamento b0st4, esperando uma conclusão menos meia-boca na DLC de 180 reais KKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKK.  Mas pera aí, pô, que tem mais uma DLC de 180 reais, com uma das classes clássicas da franquia KKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKK. Fora os passes do jogo, que, mesmo depois de jogar ele inteiro, não te dão moedas suficientes para comprar o próximo. Literalmente, a única coisa decente nesse jogo são os cosméticos — que ou são caros pra caralho ou estão presos nos passes. Ou seja: você sempre vai ter que colocar mais dinheiro no jogo, mesmo tendo farmado o passe anterior inteiro.  Enquanto isso, o POE2 se sobressai em todos os aspectos, com um jogo que respeita a comunidade e não deixa seus jogadores e fãs reféns de um jogo m3rd4, caro e com DLCs que repetem exatamente as mesmas práticas já citadas.  Enfiaram uma série consagrada no meio do rabo por causa de dinheiro, colocaram uns engravatados pau no cu pra administrar uma franquia da qual eles não têm o mínimo conhecimento. Comprei esse jogo na pré-venda, até me diverti razoavelmente devido a nostalgia, mas NÃO VALE o preço.  Sugestões do que fazer com 300 reais ao invés de comprar essa caçamba de lixo: - Usar 300 reais de maconha; - Comprar Boobie Goods; - Jogar no tigrinho; - Comprar Cigarro (se você defende a Blizzard, só pode comprar o com aviso de broxa); - Comprar um presente pra sua namorada (se não tiver, encontre sua pr0st1tut4 favorita); - Pagar a conta de luz superfaturada nesse país fodido; - Comprar qualquer outro jogo que não seja da Blizzard; - Presentear seu pai com um labubu; - Pagar seu imposto favorito (amo pagar imposto, obrigado Lula); - Jogar na Mega da Virada; - Parcelar um curso de coach motivacional (Marçal é uma opção maravilhosa para esse fim); - Terapia pra tratar o coringamento progressivo (viver não é fácil); - Comprar panetone dormido pós-natal em promoção; - Pagar a pensão atrasada do seu filho (me perdoe Lorenzo). *Lista a ser atualizada com outras opções melhores do que desperdiçar seu dinheiro com uma empresa miserável, asquerosa e filha da put4.*

I just want to rebuttal all the people complaining about new players getting Vessel of Hatred for free if they purchase Lord of Hatred. I have like an hour and a half in D4 and have refunded it since servers were miserable when I played.  Can you imagine if you still had to purchase every instance of WoW from Vanilla -> TWW just to play Midnight? Let's say they stay at $30, you'd have to spend $330 for Vanilla -> TWW, then $50 on Midnight. $380 to start playing the game. Say you want to stay subbed, that's $155 a year. Also it's impossible to make gold, so you have to spend an additional $60 on WoW tokens just to have a windfall.  Thankfully, you haven't had to buy every single expac for a while, and instead you can spend $50 for Midnight, however many months of sub you want, and skip the tokens.  These are live service games. The difference is that WoW costs a hell of a lot more than just time to play. D4 doesn't have a sub fee, it just has an egregious MTX shop. By the time Lord of Hatred launches, Vessel of Hatred will almost be a 2 year old expansion.   Now, if two-to-three months after Lord of Hatred comes out, it's on sale for $25, that's something to be upset about. Especially since this is a highly possible outcome. However to complain that buying Lord of Hatred gets new players Vessel of Hatred for free is just dumb. It's how Blizzard has managed their expacs for a while and seeing that D4 has a high chance of taking the WoW route of being a permanent entity that just receives expacs, this is how it is going to go.

Got it since it was on sale, just the base game. Definitely in a much better state than at launch. I was kind of surprised how easy this was to get back into. It's scratching an itch and I'll probably end up getting the expansion.   The only real downside that I can see currently is as others have stated, the pricing structure and microtransactions (that really don't feel necessary for you to enjoy the game, luckily). Do you get your bang for your buck? I'd say, so far the answer is yes. They've done a good job expanding on the core systems and giving enough carrots to chase that I'm happy to say I'm pleasantly surprised at how much fun I'm having.   But if you're pinching pennies, POE2 might be more so the way to go though personally I think Diablo still has the more compelling universe and aesthetic. Pick your poison.

I bought Diablo IV on Battle.net when it launched and had a lot of fun for the first few months, and then I stopped playing. Coming back, I picked it up here for achievements and to avoid having to use Battle.net.   Diablo IV is still Diablo. Level, tear into hordes for loot, and repeat ad infinitum. You don't have to no-life the game each season, but you can if you need to, and you'll find a lot of people grinding the same content. There's a lot to do, the classes are fun, and the world feels varied enough that your first time through it will be a fun sightseeing adventure.   Yes, the seasons are paid. Yes, cosmetics are expensive at around $28 USD each. If you choose to play a seasonal character, my advice is to finish the season pass (free or paid) and go until you're done for the season. There is literally no need to grind to Paragon 300 each season or chase a perfect build unless you're pushing yourself for your own reasons. If you choose to play an eternal character, have fun and enjoy the game at your own pace.   I give Diablo IV nine loot drops out of ten. That last loot drop is lost in the little details the devs always seem to overlook or meddle with each season, but the fun remains, so nine loot drops it is.

Game has gone downhill since its initial release. I feel like with every update and new DLC, the game becomes more and more annoying to play. Less responsive, clunkier, slower paced. All while enemies feel the exact opposite(enemies feel faster with better AI). While the enemies becoming more difficult doesn't seem bad(I like a challenge just as much as anyone else), the "challenge" feels like I've been nerfed from each new season. I have to play on the easiest difficulty which strikes a nerve for me, personally, just to start out the new season. I wish the game felt better to play(comparing to PoE2 which feels amazing right now), not easier, just less clunky and faster paced with more difficulty settings or making the first two or three difficulties a bit easier because you have suboptimal setups for that stage of the game. For anyone trying this game, thinking it's like Diablo 3, I can honestly say don't get it. With all my heart. Love Diablo 3, hate Diablo 4. Wish this game never came out

推荐｜真正回归“暗黑味道”的一代  《暗黑破坏神4》是我这几年玩得最“对味”的暗黑系列作品之一。整体基调从画面、美术到叙事，都彻底回归了黑暗、压抑、残酷的风格，不再是偏卡通或爽游向，而是那种让人愿意慢慢沉浸其中的暗黑世界。  战斗手感扎实，技能打击感明显，不同职业的玩法差异很清楚，不是简单换皮。Build 深度足够，前期好上手，后期研究空间也很大，喜欢刷装备、研究词条和BD的玩家会非常有参与感。  剧情表现比预期好很多，过场、配音和氛围营造都很在线，尤其是主线推进过程中那种压迫感和宗教感，很有早期暗黑的味道。世界是开放式的，但并不空洞，支线任务质量也明显高于传统“跑腿任务”。  赛季机制持续更新，让游戏始终有新目标可追，不管是休闲玩家每天刷一会，还是硬核玩家冲高层、极限配装，都能找到自己的节奏。  当然，它不是完美的：后期内容节奏、数值平衡、个别系统还在不断调整中，但整体方向是正确的，而且能看出官方在持续打磨。  总结一句： 如果你喜欢偏黑暗风格、重视氛围、成长曲线清晰、可以长期投入的ARPG，这一代值得一玩，而且越玩越顺。

Mein Fazit warum ich es dennoch empfehle steht ganz unten, danke Steam das es kein "Jein" oder "Ausgeglichen" als Empfehlung gibt. [h3] Einleitung [/h3] Uff Diablo 4... Ich denke ich fange mal mit einer Persönlichen Ranking des franchise an. 1. Diablo 2 + LoD 2. Diablo 3 ab Inferno Patch 3. Diablo 1 (Für mich schlecht gealtert) 4. Diablo 3 Legacy (also derzeitiges) 5. Diablo 4 6. Diablo Imortal  [h2] Erläuterung [/h2]  Diablo 3 war zu Release eine Vollkatastrophe, Echtgeld Auktionshaus, Vollkommen Random drops, da kam es vor, das auf einer Babarenwaffe sowohl Int, als auch Geschick drauf war. Aber das Schlimmste war der Inferno Modus. Wer keine Ahnung von Diablo hat... Diablo kann mehrmals mit dem selben Charakter durchgespielt werden, Inferno war der letzte Schwierigkeitsgrad. Inferno war nicht schwer, sondern unfair. als Melee musste man seinen Mainstat ignorieren, damit man durch Int, Wiederstände gegen alle andere Schadensarten bekam. Das wurde mit dem "Inferno Patch" etwas gefixt. Inferno wurde massiv leichter gemacht und es wurde das sogenannte "Smart Loot" System eingeführt, das mit Steigender warscheinlichkeit dir ein Gegenstand gegeben hat, das du auch wirklich nutzen kannst. Dieses System wurde weiterentwickelt bis Reaper of Souls, das Auktionshaus wurde abgeschafft und Diablo 3 wurde ein solides spiel.  [h2] Was hat das mit Diablo 4 zu tun? [/h2] Erstmal gar nichts.  Die Kritik an Diablo 3 seit Release bestand darin, dass es zu bunt ist. Während Diablo 1+2 eher einen trüben ausgewaschenen Look haben, flasht Diablo 3 regelrecht mit der Farbe.  Die Kritik ging auch an die Entwickler, die darauf hin ein Level geschaffen haben das wirklich bunt war. Das Sogenannte Ponylevel (Grafschaft Launebach), das aus Wolken, Regenbogen und Einhörnern sowie Teddybären bestand. Auf diese Kritik hat man reagiert und Diablo 4 wieder trist beziehungsweise entsättigt gemacht.  [h2] Zu Diablo 4 [/h2] Mit Diablo 4 wollte man "back to the roots". Meiner Meinung nach: Nein!, Erst einmal Premium Währung in einem Vollpreisspiel, Battlepass, ein Pausemenü wie aus Dota. Charakter Progression fühlt sich für mich wie non existent an, ich dümpel mit 71 HP auf Level 21 herum. Mein Kernangriff macht 3 + Burndamage, (spiele Zauberer). Der Skilltree wird als Immersiv angepriesen, ist aber aber im endeffekt ein Diablo 3  Skiltree mit Christbaumschmuck. Eine Richtige open World finde ich in Diablo sogar gut, aber in den 5 Stunden(Stand des Reviews) habe ich nur Schnee gesehen, es sieht alles gleich aus.  Dann zum Technischen: Always On gab es schon in Diablo 3. In Diablo 4 wird das System einfach weitergetrieben.... Pausieren als Soloplayer? Was ist das? Nett, jetzt darf ich mich entscheiden ob ich meinen Hardcore Char auf dem ich 1000hr+ habe verrecken lasse oder mein Kind dass gerade eine Nuss gegessen hat und daran erstickt. Diablo war auch schon immer ein spiel in dem ich mich entscheiden konnte, online, in LAN oder für mich selbst zu spielen, man ist aber inzwischen immer in einem Multiplayer game. Dazu noch eine kleine Sache: sobald Funktionen freigeschaltet werden, plopt das erklärungsfenster auf.... was wäre so schwer gewesen, wie z.B. in WoW oder D3 ein Symbol in UI mit neuen Infos einzufügen, Mehrseitige Fenster liest niemand, wenn direkt darunter der "Schließen" Button ist der schon auf Seite 1 klickbar ist. Was mich auch Stört ist, dass das "ESC" Menü nur ein Untermenü des Hauptscreen ist.  Grafisch sieht das spiel wirklich top aus, wobei "top" auch das manko ist, in topdown kommt eben das leveldesign nicht zu geltung.  [h2] Abschliesende Review [/h2]  Wer Mit Diablo 3 wirklich Spaß hat, sollte dabei bleiben, Diablo 3 ist flüssiger zu spielen. Für Leute die mit Diablo 3 nichts anfangen konnte, könnte es eventuell etwas sein, u.A. langsameres gameplay, ich selbst empfinde es als zu leicht.

One of my all-time favorites. I have way more hours on my Xbox Series X from before I switched to PC, so don't let my hours deceive ya! I will say though, I am not a fan of how they've changed some of the battle pass stuff and UI for the season, reliquaries, etc. but that might be my dislike for change. Regardless, I always have a blast playing this game and you don't need to let the micro transactions get ya to enjoy it. It's not pay to win!

Obviously I played the game for just under 2 hours, so I won't be reviewing endgame content - but, I do think my opinions and experience within those first two hours will be relevant to some group of players.  For my first playthrough, I intended to proceed through the campaign, although you ARE given the option to skip it, which, like in Diablo 3, allows you to somewhat effectively move into endgame content (or rather, endgame content structure, not being limited by the story/campaign). Even though I DID choose to move through the campaign, not skipping anything, the world is FLOODED with non-campaign, multiplayer-centric, store-centric, end-game-focused intrusions. Town are filled with dailies, meant for players at endgame, that may confuse new players trying to progress the campaign. Icons pop up everywhere, on the minimap and hovering over NPC heads, typically pointing you to some new (hence the indicator) cosmetic item you can buy from the shop related to that given vendor (the stable has a notification for cosmetics you can buy for your mounts, the stash has a notification for enhancements you buy for your stash, the <pet table?> has a notification indicating that there are cosmetics you can buy for your pets).  Towns are also filled with NPCs meant for features you can't access until you've reached some point in the game - a certain level, finishing a certain quest, etc... Not only does this further contribute to bloat, it makes the world feel lifeless and really shoves in your face "THIS IS A VIDEO GAME". It's kind of jarring walking up to an NPC in town only to be met with an error message stating <MUST BE LEVEL 25 TO ACCESS THIS CONTENT> - The NPC doesn't even have generic voice dialogue or anything, just a soulless NPC sitting there locked behind an error message. Oh, but don't you worry, even though you can't access these NPCs yet, their icons still show up on the minimap, leading you to believe they are something worth investigating.  Combat, honestly, just feels like Diablo 3, so I can't praise or critique it much in that regard. If you enjoyed Diablo 3, you'll probably enjoy this.  Overall, the reason I didn't give it more than 2 hours of time was so I could get my Steam Refund and because I was already fed up with trying to figure out which content was relevant to me at all. All I wanted to do was move through the campaign, not interrupted by multiplayer features, store notifications, or bloat, and it was absolutely impossible. It became immediately clear that I'd suffer through this all the way through the campaign, and it was totally distracting. I'd have no issue with all of these things opening up as they became available, or at endgame, as appropriate, but it was just so cluttered and annoying to see a bunch of crap I couldn't interact with or content that had nothing to do with the campaign that I had to sift through.

Review Title: I came for fun. I stayed because I forgot what real life feels like.  I launched this game “just to try it for 10 minutes.”  That was a lie. A disgusting, shameful lie.  Suddenly it was 3 AM, my room was dark, my soul was empty, and I was emotionally attached to pixels on a screen. This game didn’t just entertain me — it adopted me.  Let’s talk about gameplay. It’s smooth. Too smooth. Like “butter sliding on another butter” smooth. The controls feel so natural that at some point I forgot I was pressing buttons and started believing my keyboard and mouse were extensions of my nervous system.  Graphics? Absolutely beautiful. Sometimes I stopped playing just to stare at the environment like a confused tourist who forgot why he opened the game in the first place. My PC fans started praying for mercy, but honestly? Worth it.  Sound design deserves its own paragraph. The music doesn’t just play — it whispers to your soul. I caught myself doing dramatic head nods during intense moments like I was in a movie montage. My neighbors probably think I’m training for something important. I am. Survival.  Now the story… I won’t spoil anything, but let’s just say I laughed, I panicked, I questioned my moral choices, and at one point I just sat there staring at the screen thinking, “Wow… I really did that, huh?”  Replayability? Yes. Absolutely yes. I told myself I was done, closed the game, reopened it 20 minutes later “just to check something,” and somehow started a whole new run. The game won. I accepted defeat.  Bugs? A few. But honestly they felt like emotional support bugs. We struggled together.  Who should buy this game?  People who enjoy fun  People who enjoy suffering  People who say “one more mission” and then forget their own name  People who value their sleep but are willing to sacrifice it  Who should NOT buy this game?  Anyone with responsibilities  Anyone who needs to wake up early  Anyone who thinks they have self-control  Final Verdict: This game didn’t just take my time. It took my heart. 10/10 would lose track of reality again.  👍 Recommended 🏆 Please give award so my suffering was not in vain

Well...they got me. The paladin lured me back in (nostalgia) and some reddit post about the leveling experience being better.   Let me say this, I bought this game on xbox at release and played a lot of it. I can't remember which season I stopped but I think it was when they changed the leveling experience.  But before that, the leveling felt rewarding, you had time to process every new items, new talent points, your build mattered and it didnt take 2 min per levels. There was a progression and that felt good to me, some of you may disagree but I love the journey, not the goal.   Fast forward to now, I built myself a new pc and was tempted by the paladin. Oh boy...what a mistake...my heart bleeds devs of diablo 4 what have you done to your game !?!?!? It really stings badly that I bought your game a second time plus a preorder for that new class bait.  In two hours I think I've reach lvl 33 or something. I could have put my talents anywhere...wouldn't make a difference. At level 5 I got handed a unique weapon which got 173 str on it as that new season mechanic sanctify ? Let me ask you this...what is the damn point of a unique sword at level 5 when you level so fast you're gonna replace it in the next 15 min ?   Around level 15 I had legendary items thrown at me. Loot goblins flying everywhere...leveling so fucking fast I couldn't even take time to look at my talents and test out each new abilities. Forget about gear...it stays equiped for a very short time since it's raining gear basically. Now i'm left wondering if I should refund the game, or try to get to endgame and endure the shit show that is leveling in the hopes that later levels are better ? Or that endgame is worth it which I highly doubt.   Oh yeah...I forgot to say I was playing on hard difficulty like I used to for leveling. Anyhow...I hope the devs read this, I used to like this game. Guess ill go back to my druid bear build on path of exile 2...which is amazing by the way. But if anyone can help, is it better later in the game ? or does it stays like this the whole way ? Depending on your answers I'll refund or not.

Nach rund 70 Stunden Spielzeit verliert das Spiel für mich deutlich an Reiz. Das stundenlange Grinden, kombiniert mit einem monotonen und sich ständig wiederholenden Gameplay aus immergleichen Dungeons, wirkt schnell wie austauschbare 08/15-Kost. Selbst nach etwa 130 Paragon-Leveln stellt sich kaum noch Motivation ein, weiterzuspielen.  Besonders frustrierend ist das Item- und Effektsystem. Man investiert sehr viel Zeit, um Ausrüstung mühsam zu erfarmen und aufzuwerten, nur um am Ende festzustellen, dass die erhaltenen Boni nicht einmal zu dem Skill passen, den man aktiv nutzt. Damit verbunden ist ein weiteres zentrales Problem: Man ist faktisch gezwungen, sich früh auf einen einzelnen Skill festzulegen und das gesamte Build kompromisslos darauf auszurichten. Abweichungen oder Experimente fühlen sich kaum spielbar an, da man sonst spürbar ins Hintertreffen gerät.  Das Paragon-System ist grundsätzlich solide, leidet jedoch unter fragwürdigen Designentscheidungen. Viele der gelben Knoten erfordern extrem hohe Werte in völlig unpassenden Attributen. So muss man beispielsweise als Magier nahezu 1.000 Geschicklichkeit investieren, um lediglich 20 % mehr Schaden gegen Elitegegner zu erhalten – eine Designentscheidung, die weder logisch noch motivierend wirkt.  Auch das Skill-System von Level 1 bis 60 überzeugt nur bedingt. Zahlreiche Fähigkeiten erscheinen überflüssig oder passen schlicht nicht zu gängigen Builds. In meinem Fall laufe ich immer noch mit rund 20 unverteilten Skillpunkten herum, da diese für mein Build nutzlos sind oder keinen spürbaren Mehrwert bieten.  Die Story ist einmal spielenswert, darüber hinaus jedoch kaum von Bedeutung. Einmal durchgespielt, Lilith beispielsweise mit einem Dornen-Paladin im AFK-Modus besiegt, reicht das Erlebnis aus – danach kann man das Spiel Deinstallation.  Abschließend versucht die Spielwelt, ein MMO-ähnliches System zu imitieren, bleibt dabei jedoch blass. Die Map ist gefüllt mit generischen Quests, wie man sie bereits aus unzähligen anderen Spielen kennt, ohne eigene Akzente oder erinnerungswürdige Besonderheiten zu setzen.
